I... I don't really know what to say here. I'm in tears after finishing the game. In most games, your friends (and yourself) don't really get a choice on when they die. It just happens, and you restart or move on. Here, you have to CHOOSE to let them go. To let yourself go. And god, I've never done anything tougher. How do you leave a world you've spent forty, fifty hours in go? How do you say, "Well, I guess this is it?" This game asks that question. It forces you to let your friends leave, after truly learning about them and loving them, because it's what they want. It's what's best.

I think, going forward, my life is forever changed. I get attached to characters so easily, and for a while, I refused to finish my final task. How could I? But, well. I did. And I think that now, maybe it'll become a little easier to let others go. Because I've had to do it, and I've come out alright.

If there's one thing I could say to anyone thinking about playing this game... DO IT. Sink hours into it. Complete every quest, every shenanigan, every achievement. Let yourself love the characters, and grapple with letting them go. I think the morals and lessons from this game is one everyone needs to hear.

To Thunder Lotus, thank you for making this game, and allowing us all a safe space to learn to process grief.

[h1] What is this game? [/h1]
Spiritfarer is a story heavy, semi-collectathon. This game puts the player in the shoes of "Stella" - a young girl who becomes the new Charon for spirits, having to give them closure before eventually sending them through the Evergate (basically death for spirits).

[h2] Price/replay value [/h2]
Horrible - Bad - [u] Decent [/u] - Good - Amazing

[h2] Achievement hunting [/h2]
All achievements can be gotten within 1 run (assuming a reload for sealed/closed lips) - none are particularly challenging, but some can be missed quite easily e.g.; [i] The Happy Dance.[/i] With proper planning this shouldn't be an issue however.

[h2] Pros/cons [/h2]
[b] Pros [/b]
[list]
[*]Amazing writing with some very realistic characters
[*]Good graphics and amazing soundtrack
[*]Very casual
[/list]

[b] Cons [/b]
[list]
[*]Starts out [i] extremely [/i] slow with very little to do
[*]Incredibly grindy sections during mid/late game
[*]Spirit pathfinding is a mess 
[/list]

[h2] Overall opinion [/h2]
Spiritfarer is not a perfect game. 
That said, I still enjoyed it a lot. The game at first really gave me the "ick" if you will, making me consider putting it down due to the tedious early game. After you chew through the tough skin that is the early game though, you'll be blessed with a deliciously juicy game that offers a ton of interesting characters and fun dialogue. From those who yearn to die, to those who fear what the Everdoor might behold, there's a bit of everything. Sadly I can't go into depth without spoiling that though so...

The gameplay, whilst quite repetitive, does eventually start to snap into place and offers a relaxing, and smooth experience. There's fishing, gardening, woodsawing... All having little minigames that you get to learn and get better at, making your resource production increase alongside your skill level. 
The main traversal is via a map which simply requires choosing a location and you'll ship automatically go there. Whilst the controls could've used a bit more depth, it overall feels fine and responsive. The game also often does encourage going to unknown dark spots of the map so the player can find secret or obscure islands and treasures.


[h2] tldr; [/h2]
Very laid back, with a beautiful story.

[h2] Should you buy it? [/h2] 
Go for it if you prefer story driven games. If you only care about gameplay, then this isn't for you.

TL;DR - The game starts off interesting enough to pull your attention -- then drops the ball as the game progresses with poorly thought out resource management, and tedious repetition for gameplay length padding.

The majority of negative reviews hit this one on the mark. Someone came up with an okay story idea, but didn't have a well thought out plan of how to convert that into a long gameplay experience.

The resource management in the game is ridiculous, and only gets more tedious as the game progresses. There is an excessive amount of backtracking that is made more cumbersome by not being able to custom mark the map for things like abilities needed for certain areas or goals not yet met. There are a good amount of fast travel points, but it still does not offset the need to write down or remember special attributes about each island that you may have to revisit later due to inaccessible areas.

The gameplay loop starts to get stale after the first couple of completions as the loop does not really change much as you progress further into the story. You get some fetch quests, upgrade homes, then turn them in. The character stories are okay, but there's not too much depth to the characters themselves to pull you into what ails them.

Eventually you kind of just stop caring at all what they have to say. You become a dead husk inside from the tedium. As a consequence of this, you kind of start speeding through the dialog so you can take their next request, grind the necessary resources, and then send them on their way -- Spiritfarer: Jaded Edition.

The hand drawn art is well done, and the character design is neat. Music helps pass the time in game, but it isn't something that will get stuck in your head. Player control is solid, and game customization like display options and control mapping is done well.

This game was one that I was going to think was okay if you got it on sale. However, after putting more and more time into it to see what direction the game takes after you sink a good chunk of time into it, I really just ended up wishing I hadn't wasted the time I had already put into it.

Devs seem to have struck gold with a certain audience that eats this up writing essays about how the stories made them cry their eyes out, without a single mention of the plethora of flaws this game has. For me, after giving it two chances, 10 hours of playtime each, I can confidently say that there are way too many things wrong with the actual gameplay for me to recommend this game. I continued playing where I stopped last year, and a couple hours in it became clear again why I got tired of playing this game:

Spiritfarer as a videogame is basically tedium in fancy clothes, looks and sounds good but when it comes to the actual gameplay elements? Good Lord what were they thinking... Every single task takes an eternity and has to be repeated in full hundreds of times throughout a playthrough, from the stale minigames to the long and slow animations, farming, mining, cutting trees, processing resources, it all takes such an insanely long time that I really can't be bothered anymore. Each and every single item has to be added one by one to boot, there is no slider or "add max" button, nothing, if you want to process 50 logs of wood, guess what? You're pressing that "add" button 50 freakin times... only to then manually saw each individual piece during a repetitive mini game. For the last 3 hours in this game I've just constantly been asking myself "why did they not let players unlock "auto" mode after repeating the manual process a set number of times?", it really, really feels like playtime was padded in the worst way possible, making you repeat tedious needless actions ad nauseam.

To expand on this a bit further: Take planting crops for example. You build a garden which has 3 plots of land, you put a seed in every plot, every single time you plant a seed, an animation plays. Then you need to water each individual plot separately because why not, and of course another slow animation plays. You'd think that'd be that, now it's waiting time! But nahh, you'll need to water them AGAIN before the plants mature. And that's just a single garden lmao... You could have 4 gardens and 4 fields (or, God forbid, even more), that's 24 plots of land, yeah, it gets insanely tedious. All of this would have been forgiven if you could just upgrade your buildings to maybe automatically water your plants, but no, you'll be doing it manually for literally dozens of hours, hundreds perhaps thousands of times. And that's just your plants, you want to milk cows? Watch a slow milking animation, then watch an animation of the cow lying down, because you can't feed the cow until it finishes the animation, and then you feed the cow or it won't produce milk again over time. Picking apples from your tree? Yeah, watch your character slowly touch the tree until the apples fall off. I mean, what are we doing here, this isn't a chill game, this is watching paint dry almost taken literally.

On top of all of this, progression is literally just fetch quest after fetch quest, the game constantly sends you back and forth to islands across the map that are all filled with tall buildings that you can enter, but that don't contain a single thing, you can climb them from the inside, but there's no purpose, it's annoying, it's frustrating, it makes me feel like my time is being intentionally wasted. Traversing the map is painfully slow for most of the playthrough as well, and if you pass through an optional event to collect resources, your boat will stop in it's track without exceptions and you'll have to first interact with an NPC on your ship in order to skip the event. Why, just why?...

There's more small annoyances all over, like your map being inaccessible at night because you can't sail your ship after dark. Ok, but why am I being prevented from seeing the map and planning where I want to sail the next day? It just doesn't make any sense at all, like many things in Spiritfarer.

I'll probably try to finish my run but after 20 hours I am completely and utterly done with the tedious nature of every single repetitive task, and it looks like I'm not even halfway done with the story, so that's promising. It will take some serious surprises to make me change my opinion on this one, not recommended for people who are looking for actual fun gameplay, recommended for people who get emotional easily and have never played an actually fun and engaging resource management game I guess?

TL;DR - The game starts off interesting enough to pull your attention -- then drops the ball as the game progresses with poorly thought out resource management, and tedious repetition for gameplay length padding.

The majority of negative reviews hit this one on the mark. Someone came up with an okay story idea, but didn't have a well thought out plan of how to convert that into a long gameplay experience.

The resource management in the game is ridiculous, and only gets more tedious as the game progresses. There is an excessive amount of backtracking that is made more cumbersome by not being able to custom mark the map for things like abilities needed for certain areas or goals not yet met. There are a good amount of fast travel points, but it still does not offset the need to write down or remember special attributes about each island that you may have to revisit later due to inaccessible areas.

The gameplay loop starts to get stale after the first couple of completions as the loop does not really change much as you progress further into the story. You get some fetch quests, upgrade homes, then turn them in. The character stories are okay, but there's not too much depth to the characters themselves to pull you into what ails them.

Eventually you kind of just stop caring at all what they have to say. You become a dead husk inside from the tedium. As a consequence of this, you kind of start speeding through the dialog so you can take their next request, grind the necessary resources, and then send them on their way -- Spiritfarer: Jaded Edition.

The hand drawn art is well done, and the character design is neat. Music helps pass the time in game, but it isn't something that will get stuck in your head. Player control is solid, and game customization like display options and control mapping is done well.

This game was one that I was going to think was okay if you got it on sale. However, after putting more and more time into it to see what direction the game takes after you sink a good chunk of time into it, I really just ended up wishing I hadn't wasted the time I had already put into it.

Devs seem to have struck gold with a certain audience that eats this up writing essays about how the stories made them cry their eyes out, without a single mention of the plethora of flaws this game has. For me, after giving it two chances, 10 hours of playtime each, I can confidently say that there are way too many things wrong with the actual gameplay for me to recommend this game. I continued playing where I stopped last year, and a couple hours in it became clear again why I got tired of playing this game:

Spiritfarer as a videogame is basically tedium in fancy clothes, looks and sounds good but when it comes to the actual gameplay elements? Good Lord what were they thinking... Every single task takes an eternity and has to be repeated in full hundreds of times throughout a playthrough, from the stale minigames to the long and slow animations, farming, mining, cutting trees, processing resources, it all takes such an insanely long time that I really can't be bothered anymore. Each and every single item has to be added one by one to boot, there is no slider or "add max" button, nothing, if you want to process 50 logs of wood, guess what? You're pressing that "add" button 50 freakin times... only to then manually saw each individual piece during a repetitive mini game. For the last 3 hours in this game I've just constantly been asking myself "why did they not let players unlock "auto" mode after repeating the manual process a set number of times?", it really, really feels like playtime was padded in the worst way possible, making you repeat tedious needless actions ad nauseam.

To expand on this a bit further: Take planting crops for example. You build a garden which has 3 plots of land, you put a seed in every plot, every single time you plant a seed, an animation plays. Then you need to water each individual plot separately because why not, and of course another slow animation plays. You'd think that'd be that, now it's waiting time! But nahh, you'll need to water them AGAIN before the plants mature. And that's just a single garden lmao... You could have 4 gardens and 4 fields (or, God forbid, even more), that's 24 plots of land, yeah, it gets insanely tedious. All of this would have been forgiven if you could just upgrade your buildings to maybe automatically water your plants, but no, you'll be doing it manually for literally dozens of hours, hundreds perhaps thousands of times. And that's just your plants, you want to milk cows? Watch a slow milking animation, then watch an animation of the cow lying down, because you can't feed the cow until it finishes the animation, and then you feed the cow or it won't produce milk again over time. Picking apples from your tree? Yeah, watch your character slowly touch the tree until the apples fall off. I mean, what are we doing here, this isn't a chill game, this is watching paint dry almost taken literally.

On top of all of this, progression is literally just fetch quest after fetch quest, the game constantly sends you back and forth to islands across the map that are all filled with tall buildings that you can enter, but that don't contain a single thing, you can climb them from the inside, but there's no purpose, it's annoying, it's frustrating, it makes me feel like my time is being intentionally wasted. Traversing the map is painfully slow for most of the playthrough as well, and if you pass through an optional event to collect resources, your boat will stop in it's track without exceptions and you'll have to first interact with an NPC on your ship in order to skip the event. Why, just why?...

There's more small annoyances all over, like your map being inaccessible at night because you can't sail your ship after dark. Ok, but why am I being prevented from seeing the map and planning where I want to sail the next day? It just doesn't make any sense at all, like many things in Spiritfarer.

I'll probably try to finish my run but after 20 hours I am completely and utterly done with the tedious nature of every single repetitive task, and it looks like I'm not even halfway done with the story, so that's promising. It will take some serious surprises to make me change my opinion on this one, not recommended for people who are looking for actual fun gameplay, recommended for people who get emotional easily and have never played an actually fun and engaging resource management game I guess?
